interpretation_summary: The replication attempted to test the hypothesis that political polarization negatively affects government size in strong democracies. The replication used the 2010 wave of the World Values Survey, while the original study used the 2000 wave. The analysis was executed successfully, but the results did not support the hypothesis, as the coefficient for political polarization was not statistically significant.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: Full alignment: The replication used regression analysis with specified variables and control variables, matching the original study's methodology.

deviations.issue_description: Dataset used the 2010 wave instead of the 2000 wave.
deviations.impact: Moderate: The change in dataset wave may have affected the results due to differences in sample characteristics.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Among strong democracies (countries with a Polity IV score of 9 or greater), polarization (as measured by the SD of the 'private ownership' responses) will be negatively associated with the size of government.
results_comparison.overall_answer: No, the replication results did not satisfy the preregistered comparison criteria for the focal claim.

replication_report: Replication unsuccessful: The effect of political polarization on government size was not statistically significant in the replication study.

failure_handling.suggestions: Consider using the same wave of the World Values Survey as the original study to ensure comparability.

notes: The results may be sensitive to the choice of dataset wave. Future replications should consider using the same wave as the original study to minimize differences in sample characteristics.
